Each function invocation defines its own context. Therefore, the

In the strict mode, JavaScript sets the

//
"use strict";

function show() {
    console.log(this === undefined);
}

show();Code language: JavaScript (javascript)
To enable the strict mode, you use the directive
at the beginning of the JavaScript file. If you want to apply the strict mode to a specific function only, you place it at the top of the function body.
Note that the strict mode has been available since ECMAScript 5.1. The
mode applies to both function and nested functions. For example:

//


function show() {
    "use strict";
    console.log(this === undefined); // true

    function display() {
        console.log(this === undefined); // true
    }
    display();
}

show();Code language: JavaScript (javascript)

When you call a method of an object, JavaScript sets
to the object that owns the method. See the following

//
let car = {
    brand: 'Honda',
    getBrand: function () {
        return this.brand;
    }
}

console.log(car.getBrand()); // HondaCode language: JavaScript (javascript)
Since a method is a property of an object which is a value, you can store it in a variable.

Since an arrow function does not create its own execution context, defining a method using an arrow function will cause an issue. For example:

//


function Car() {
    this.speed = 120;
}

Car.prototype.getSpeed = () => {
    return this.speed;
}

var car = new Car();
car.getSpeed(); // TypeErrorCode language: JavaScript (javascript)
